awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Social and Behavioral Aspects of the West Virginia Chemical Spill and Water Crisis
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
On January 9, 2014, Freedom Industries in Charleston, West Virginia spilled 10,000 gallons of chemicals, including 4-methylcyclohexanemethanol (MCHM), from their storage tanks, an unknown portion of which then flowed into the Elk River, the main water source for West Virginia American Water. After discovering the contamination, the State issued a Do Not Use Order for 300,000 people in 9 counties of West Virginia. Over the next several months, residents of the affected areas were presented with conflicting orders and large gaps in information by the state government, the CDC, West Virginia American Water, and Freedom Industries. Thus the relationship between the residents and officials guiding the response to the water crisis was strained at best and severely damaged at worst.

The goal of “Social and Behavioral Aspects of the West Virginia Chemical Spill and Water Crisis” was to discern the rhetorical missteps on the part of public officials and the news media, understand how historically exploitation by extractive and chemical industries influenced the public’s response to these missteps, understand how these rhetorics continue to endanger the public, and design interventions in these discourses. Research consisted of conducting 55 video and audio interviews with residents affected by the water crisis as well as activists, researchers, and officials involved in the water crisis response and recovery. The West Virginia Water Crisis website (www.wvwatercrisis.com) hosts 40 videos and 67 blog posts containing these interviews and footage of public meetings, protests, and other water crisis-related events.

In addition to creating a public rhetorical space for unheard stories about the human impact of the crisis, the site provided crucial scientific and public health information from the University of Alabama engineering research team headed by Dr. Andrew Whelton. Viewed thousands of times, the plumbing flushing instructions video prevented more residents from following the official flushing instructions and being exposed to dangerous fumes. This video was cited in The New York Times and helped increase the visibility of independent academic research that eventually came to prominence in the state-funded West Virginia Testing and Assessment Project.

The West Virginia Water Crisis website also became a national and international resource for information on the water crisis, with over 42,000 visits from over 85 countries. Video footage from the site has been used in a Science Nation video, and interviews with Dr. Bryson, regarding the event’s place in Appalachian history were featured in Al-Jazeera America, Environmental Science and Technology, and Newsweek. Another NSF-funded research project–Virginia Tech study on the Flint Michigan water contamination–cited the water crisis website as inspiration for their own website.

Using a combination of rhetorical and discourse analysis, Dr. Bryson interpreted interviews with West Virginia Water Crisis victims, researchers, and advocates, furthering the development of an Appalachian regional rhetorical theory. Initial findings from this research are reported in Dr. Bryson’s dissertation, A Regional Rhetoric for Advocacy in Appalachia, and have also been disseminated via 11 academic conference presentations and invited lectures.

This research demonstrates how Dr. Bryson’s concept of a regional rhetoric in Appalachia could be implemented by more than just Appalachian nonprofits; it can be used by scientists, government officials, and the media to more effectively communicate with the public during times of crisis and discussions of environmental injustice.
